div.l: The miller is a ꝑperlious man he seide
And if that he oute of his slepe abreide
He might done vs both vilalye
Aleyn answerde I counte him nat a flye
And vp he riste and by the wench he crepte
This wench lay vpright and faste slepte
Till he so nygh were er she might spye
That it hadde ben to late for to crye
And shortly for to seyne they were at one
Nowe pley aleyn for I woll speke of Iohn
This Iohn lith stille a furlonge wey or twoo
And to him self he maketh routh and woo
Allas quoth he this ys a wrecched Iape
Nowe may I seyne that I is but an ape
Yet hath my felawe somewhat for his harme
He hath the millers doughter in his arme
He auntred him and hath his erandes spedde
And I lye as a draffe sak in my bedde
And whenne this iape is tolde another day
I shall ben holde a daffe a cokenaye
I wille arise and aunter me by my feith
Vnhardy vnsely thus men seith
And vp he roos and softely he wente
Vnto the cradell and softely itte hente
And bare itte softe vntoo his beddes fete
Sone after the wife hir rowtinge lete
And ganne awake and went hir for to pisse
And com̄me ageyne and ganne the cradell mysse
And gropeth here and there but she founde none
Allas quoth shee I hadde almoste mys gone
I had almoste gone to the clerkes bedde
Ey benedicite thenne hadde I foule spedde
And forth she goth till she the cradell fonde
She gropeth alwey further with hir honde
And founde the bedde and thought nat but gode
By cause that the cradell by ytte stode
And nyste where she was for itte was derke
But feire and wele she crepte yn to the clerke
And lith fulle stille and wolde haue caught a slepe
Within a while this Iohn the clerke vp lepe
And on this gode wife he leith on sore
So mery a fitte she hadde nat full yore
He pricketh harde and depe as he were madde
This ioly life thise clerkes two han ledde
Tille that the thirde cok beganne to cro
Aleyne wex wery in the dawenynge
For he had swunken in i the longe night
And seid farewele malyn my swete wight
The day is come I may no lenger byde
But euer so muste I goo or ryde
I am thyne owen clerke soo haue I hele
Nowe dere lemman quod she goo fare wele
But er thou goo oo thinge I will the tell
Whenne thou wendest homewarde by the melle
Right at the entre of the dore behinde
Thou shalte a cake of halfe a busshell fynde
That was y maked of thyne owene mele
Which I halpe my fader for to stele
Taketh all youre gere feire to hepe
Aleyne vp riste and thought er it were dawe
And founde the cradell with his honde anone
By godde thought he all wrange I gone
Myne hede is toty of my slepe to night
That maketh me that I goo nat aright
I wote welle by the cradell I haue mysgoo
Here lith the miller and his wife alsoo
And forth he gooth on twenty deuell weye
Vn to the bedde there as the miller laye
He wende haue crope ynne by his felawe Iohn
And by the miller yn he crepte anone
And caught him by the nek and softe he spake
And seid thou Iohn thou swynes hede awake
For cristes soule and here a noble game
For by that lorde that cleped is seint Iame
As I haue thries on this shorte night
Swyued the millers doughter bolte vpright vᵈᵉ fol. vᵒ anteAt the same postion on f. 23v, containing MI 316, the same (later) hand writes "vᵈᵉ fol. vᵒ post.
